pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 207, 280, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 250, 560, 292]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 313, 387, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 344, 235, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 359, 600, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 374, 890, 403]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 890, 445]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 445, 890, 460]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 473, 555, 489]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 503, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 98, 680, 545]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 79, 168, 94]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 109, 325, 126]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 160, 275, 176]]<|/det|>
work done on/by a gas,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 192, 262, 208]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 254, 240]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 255, 285, 271]]<|/det|>
pressure of an ideal gas,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 283, 309]]<|/det|>
simple harmonic motion,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 325, 310, 342]]<|/det|>
velocity of particle in s.h.m.,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 382, 221, 398]]<|/det|>
electric potential,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 422, 245, 439]]<|/det|>
capacitors in series,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 454, 256, 470]]<|/det|>
capacitors in parallel,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 485, 316, 502]]<|/det|>
energy of charged capacitor,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 516, 231, 533]]<|/det|>
resistors in series,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 548, 242, 564]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 580, 301, 597]]<|/det|>
alternating current/voltage,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 612, 232, 629]]<|/det|>
radioactive decay,  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 643, 215, 660]]<|/det|>
decay constant,  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 108, 570, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 160, 530, 177]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 187, 542, 216]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 225, 527, 242]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 250, 583, 281]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 292, 540, 310]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 325, 566, 343]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 349, 600, 377]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{x_0^2 - x^2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 380, 546, 410]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 421, 643, 440]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 453, 600, 471]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 484, 536, 507]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 518, 600, 536]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 549, 640, 568]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 581, 560, 599]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 612, 582, 630]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 635, 540, 670]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
When a force \(F\) moves its point of application through a displacement \(s\) in the direction of the force, the work \(W\) done by the force is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 117, 534, 134]]<|/det|>
\[W = Fs.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 752, 165]]<|/det|>
How many vector quantities and scalar quantities does this equation contain?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 520, 193]]<|/det|>
A one scalar quantity and two vector quantities

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 202, 520, 219]]<|/det|>
B one vector quantity and two scalar quantities

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 228, 337, 244]]<|/det|>
C three scalar quantities

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 337, 270]]<|/det|>
D three vector quantities

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 300, 94, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 918, 333]]<|/det|>
What is a possible unit for the product \(VI,\) where \(V\) is the potential difference across a resistor and \(I\) is the current through the same resistor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 344, 368, 360]]<|/det|>
A newton per second (N s\(^{- 1}\))

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 370, 324, 386]]<|/det|>
B newton second (N s)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 319, 412]]<|/det|>
C newton metre (N m)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 440, 438]]<|/det|>
D newton metre per second (N m s\(^{- 1}\))

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 466, 94, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 466, 918, 498]]<|/det|>
What is a reasonable estimate of the average kinetic energy of an athlete during a 100 m race that takes 10 s?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 509, 725, 526]]<|/det|>
A 40J B 400J C 4000J D 40 000J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 245, 571]]<|/det|>
<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A light-meter measures the intensity \(I\) of the light falling on it. Theory suggests that \(I\) varies inversely as the square of the distance \(d\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 116, 737, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 514, 303]]<|/det|>
Which graph of the results supports this theory?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 312, 775, 640]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 672, 245, 689]]<|/det|>
Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 781, 90]]<|/det|>
In an experiment, a radio-controlled car takes \(2.50 \pm 0.05 \text{s}\) to travel \(40.0 \pm 0.1 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 660, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the car's average speed and the uncertainty in this value?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 300, 225]]<|/det|>
A \(16\pm 1m s^{- 1}\) B \(16.0\pm 0.2m s^{- 1}\) C \(16.0\pm 0.4m s^{- 1}\) D \(16.00\pm 0.36m s^{- 1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 254, 94, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 918, 286]]<|/det|>
In an experiment to determine the acceleration of free fall using a falling body, what would lead to a value that is too large?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 298, 265, 313]]<|/det|>
A air resistance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 324, 452, 339]]<|/det|>
B dimensions of the body are too large

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 520, 365]]<|/det|>
C measured distance longer than true distance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 376, 450, 391]]<|/det|>
D measured time longer than true time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 418, 94, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 638, 434]]<|/det|>
Which feature of a graph allows acceleration to be determined?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 447, 500, 462]]<|/det|>
A the area under a displacement-time graph

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 450, 488]]<|/det|>
B the area under a velocity-time graph

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 475, 515]]<|/det|>
C the slope of a displacement-time graph

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 427, 541]]<|/det|>
D the slope of a velocity-time graph

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 570, 245, 585]]<|/det|>
<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a laboratory experiment in which a feather falls from rest in a long evacuated vertical tube of length \(L\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 115, 593, 335]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 344, 684, 362]]<|/det|>
The feather takes time \(T\) to fall from the top to the bottom of the tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 374, 724, 392]]<|/det|>
How far will the feather have fallen from the top of the tube in time \(0.50T?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 140, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 402, 205, 420]]<|/det|>
0.13 \(L\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 402, 372, 420]]<|/det|>
B 0.25 \(L\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 402, 539, 420]]<|/det|>
C 0.38 \(L\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 402, 685, 420]]<|/det|>
D 0.50 \(L\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 448, 94, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 919, 481]]<|/det|>
In the absence of air resistance, a stone is thrown from P and follows a parabolic path in which the highest point reached is T. The stone reaches point Q just before landing.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 490, 752, 560]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 571, 559, 588]]<|/det|>
The vertical component of acceleration of the stone is

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 600, 135, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 600, 234, 617]]<|/det|>
zero at T.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 628, 325, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 625, 325, 643]]<|/det|>
larger at T than at Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 325, 669]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 653, 325, 669]]<|/det|>
larger at Q than at T.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 679, 339, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 679, 339, 695]]<|/det|>
the same at Q as at T.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 723, 245, 739]]<|/det|>
<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 593, 90]]<|/det|>
Each option gives a correct word equation involving force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 463, 120]]<|/det|>
Which option gives the definition of force?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 480, 148]]<|/det|>
A force = energy divided by displacement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 159, 383, 174]]<|/det|>
B force = mass × acceleration

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 186, 350, 201]]<|/det|>
C force = pressure × area

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 212, 455, 227]]<|/det|>
D force = rate of change of momentum

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 255, 107, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 917, 272]]<|/det|>
Two similar spheres, each of mass \(m\) and travelling with speed \(v\), are moving towards each other.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 285, 640, 377]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 388, 492, 404]]<|/det|>
The spheres have a head-on elastic collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 350, 434]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 447, 460, 463]]<|/det|>
A The spheres stick together on impact.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 510, 489]]<|/det|>
B The total kinetic energy after impact is \(mv^2\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 528, 515]]<|/det|>
C The total kinetic energy before impact is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 509, 541]]<|/det|>
D The total momentum before impact is \(2mv\) .

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 570, 245, 585]]<|/det|>
# Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 107, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a barrel suspended from a frictionless pulley on a building. The rope supporting the barrel goes over the pulley and is secured to a stake at the bottom of the building.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 115, 635, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 352, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
A man stands close to the stake. The bottom of the barrel is \(18 \text{m}\) above the man's head. The mass of the barrel is \(120 \text{kg}\) and the mass of the man is \(80 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 397, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
The man keeps hold of the rope after untying it from the stake and is lifted upwards as the barrel falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 865, 476]]<|/det|>
What is the man's upward speed when his head is level with the bottom of the barrel? (Use \(g = 10 \text{m} \text{s}^{-2}\).)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 720, 504]]<|/det|>
A \(6 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) B \(8 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) C \(13 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) D \(19 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 532, 245, 548]]<|/det|>
<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 107, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 919, 125]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical block of wood has cross-sectional area \(A\) and weight \(W\). It is totally immersed in water with its axis vertical. The block experiences pressures \(\rho_{\mathrm{t}}\) and \(\rho_{\mathrm{b}}\) at its top and bottom surfaces respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 136, 574, 154]]<|/det|>
Which expression is equal to the upthrust on the block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 164, 272, 180]]<|/det|>
A \((p_{b} - p_{t})A + W\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 220, 207]]<|/det|>
B \((p_{b} - p_{t})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 216, 232, 233]]<|/det|>
C \((p_{b} - p_{t})A\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 242, 272, 258]]<|/det|>
D \((p_{b} - p_{t})A - W\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 287, 107, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 287, 919, 320]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(m\) travels at constant speed up a slope at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, as shown in the diagram. Air resistance and friction provide a resistive force \(F\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 330, 710, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 451, 628, 468]]<|/det|>
What force is needed to propel the car at this constant speed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 480, 141, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 480, 230, 497]]<|/det|>
\(mg \cos \theta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 508, 228, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 508, 228, 525]]<|/det|>
\(mg \sin \theta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 535, 262, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 535, 262, 553]]<|/det|>
\(mg \cos \theta + F\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 562, 255, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 562, 255, 580]]<|/det|>
\(mg \sin \theta + F\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 606, 245, 623]]<|/det|>
<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 515, 90]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a crane supporting a load \(L\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 101, 611, 231]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 244, 919, 276]]<|/det|>
A mass provides a balancing load \(W.\) The position of the load is such that the system is perfectly balanced with \(Wx = Ly.\) The ground provides a reaction force \(R.\) The distance \(x\) does not change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 290, 918, 322]]<|/det|>
If the load is moved further out so that the distance \(y\) increases and the crane does not topple, which statement is correct?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 332, 810, 488]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 500, 475, 532]]<|/det|>
A horizontal force \(H\) acts on the base of the support column towards the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 500, 880, 532]]<|/det|>
A horizontal force \(H\) acts on the base of the support column towards the right.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 567, 808, 720]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 736, 455, 752]]<|/det|>
The reaction force \(R\) moves to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 736, 863, 752]]<|/det|>
The reaction force \(R\) moves to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 782, 245, 798]]<|/det|>
<pre>Space for working

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
A concrete cube of side \(0.60 \text{m}\) and uniform density \(2.0 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\) is lifted \(5.0 \text{m}\) vertically by a crane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 115, 542, 133]]<|/det|>
What is the change in potential energy of the cube?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 144, 710, 161]]<|/det|>
A \(2.2 \text{kJ}\) B \(21 \text{kJ}\) C \(59 \text{kJ}\) D \(450 \text{kJ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 201, 107, 218]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 201, 919, 232]]<|/det|>
The force resisting the motion of a car is taken as being proportional to the square of the car's speed. The magnitude of the force at a speed of \(20 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) is \(800 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 244, 890, 261]]<|/det|>
What effective power is required from the car's engine to maintain a steady speed of \(40 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 720, 290]]<|/det|>
A \(32 \text{kW}\) B \(64 \text{kW}\) C \(128 \text{kW}\) D \(512 \text{kW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 318, 107, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 318, 699, 336]]<|/det|>
The data below are taken from a test of a petrol engine for a motor car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 348, 480, 365]]<|/det|>
power output \(150kW\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 375, 557, 392]]<|/det|>
fuel consumption \(20\) litres per hour

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 401, 534, 418]]<|/det|>
energy content of fuel \(40MJ\) per litre

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 431, 607, 448]]<|/det|>
Which expression will evaluate the efficiency of the engine?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 463, 136, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 350, 495]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{150\times 10^{3}}{40\times 10^{6}\times 20\times 60\times 60}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 513, 136, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 304, 545]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{150\times 10^{3}\times 60\times 60}{20\times 40\times 10^{6}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 562, 136, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 351, 594]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{150\times 10^{3}\times 40\times 10^{6}\times 20}{60\times 60}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 610, 141, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 607, 300, 642]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{150\times 10^{3}\times 20}{40\times 10^{3}\times 60\times 60}\]

<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 450, 90]]<|/det|>
What is the internal energy of an object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 141, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 101, 725, 119]]<|/det|>
It is the energy associated with the object's movement through space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 141, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 127, 850, 144]]<|/det|>
It is the energy associated with the random movement of the molecules in the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 154, 141, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 153, 759, 170]]<|/det|>
It is the energy due to the attractions between the molecules in the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 141, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 180, 919, 212]]<|/det|>
It is the sum of all the microscopic potential and kinetic energies of the molecules in the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 240, 107, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 240, 919, 272]]<|/det|>

<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
At room temperature, the density of liquid mercury is five times greater than the density of solid aluminium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 346, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 150, 164]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 147, 504, 163]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 174, 618, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 171, 618, 187]]<|/det|>
Aluminium atoms move more freely than mercury atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 199, 628, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 197, 628, 214]]<|/det|>
Atoms in a liquid take up less space than atoms in a solid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 628, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 224, 628, 240]]<|/det|>

<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 271, 919, 303]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 316, 489, 332]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 344, 356, 360]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 344, 356, 360]]<|/det|>
amorphous to polymeric

<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 370, 356, 386]]<|/det|>
crystalline to amorphous

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 344, 412]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 396, 344, 412]]<|/det|>
crystalline to polymeric

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 354, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 422, 354, 438]]<|/det|>
polymeric to amorphous

<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 640, 90]]<|/det|>
Which observation indicates that sound waves are longitudinal?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 520, 119]]<|/det|>
A Sound can be reflected from a solid surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 380, 144]]<|/det|>
B Sound cannot be polarised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 444, 170]]<|/det|>
C Sound is diffracted around corners.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 598, 196]]<|/det|>
D Sound is refracted as it passes from hot air to cold air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 107, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 919, 256]]<|/det|>
To produce a stationary wave, two waves must travel in opposite directions through the same space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 268, 728, 285]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the properties of the two waves must also be true?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 297, 790, 314]]<|/det|>
A The waves must have equal frequency, but a different speed and wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 323, 790, 339]]<|/det|>
B The waves must have equal speed, but a different wavelength and frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 672, 365]]<|/det|>
C The waves must have equal speed, frequency and wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 374, 790, 390]]<|/det|>
D The waves must have equal wavelength, but a different speed and frequency.
